intro: Ocimum lamiifolium, commonly known as wild basil, is a member of the Lamiaceae family, characterized by its aromatic leaves and square stems. It is native to tropical and subtropical regions of the Americas and thrives in warm, humid climates. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with opposite, ovate to lanceolate leaves that are often covered in fine hairs. Its small, tubular flowers are usually purple or violet, arranged in whorled clusters at the leaf axils. The essential oils extracted from its leaves contain compounds like linalool and eugenol, which contribute to its distinct fragrance and various medicinal properties.
